p.title: Iliad.
p.#text: Vs. 1-7. Prooemium:  The wrath of Achilles, from its very beginning, and the destructive consequences which followed in accordance with the will of Zeus. This is the principal theme of the  The First Book serves as an introduction to the whole poem; it narrates the story of the strife between Achilles and Agamemnon, and the decree of Zeus, which is made on the intercession of Thetis.  The events narrated in A occupy 21 days.
:  the  of ; cf. vs. 81, 247, 488. This receives prominence as being most important for the subject of the poem.

: for the single , see  41 f. Achilles was the son of Peleus and the sea-goddess Thetis (see vs. 351 ff.). He was the mightiest warrior of the Greek leaders before Troy (v. 280, ), although one of the youngest ( ff.). His home was in Phthia ( ff.) of Thessaly. See on v. 488.

To be left unburied was a dreaded fate; so Hector at the point of death besought Achilles,  339.

: tetrasyllabic,  21 f.; for the use of the patronymic, see  21 b. Agamemnon, son of Atreus, and grandson of Pelops ( ff.),  reigned at Mycenae ( ff.). As the leader of the expedition against Troy, he is prominent through the whole poem. The first part of the Eleventh Book is devoted to his brave deeds in war (). He is described by Helen as a good king and a brave warrior ().
: elsewhere precedes a proper name; only here is it found after a patronymic. It is generally applied to Agamemnon,  1 q. For the apparent hiatus, see  9 f, 14 a.

p.title: The injured Chryses. The avenging Apollo.
p.#text: Vs. 8-52.  The scene opens in the 9th year of the war before Troy (). During their siege of the city, the Greeks supported themselves by marauding expeditions. On one of these forays they captured Thebe (vs. 366 ff.) and brought away as part of the booty the daughter of Chryses, priest of Apollo (v. 370). She was assigned to Agamemnon, to be his slave, as his ,  See on vs. 124 f.

p.#text: : acc. to the later story, daughter of Tyndares and Leda, and thus half-sister of Helen. The ancient Greek on hearing these lines remembered well that Clytaemnestra proved unfaithful  to Agamemnon, and slew him on his return to his home ( ff.). She was herself slain by her son Orestes ( ff.). The deaths of Agamemnon and Clytaemnestra formed the theme of famous tragedies by the three greatest tragic poets of Greece,  the  and  of Aeschylus, the  of Sophocles, and the  of Euripides.

p.#text: .: , from which the king could be recompensed easily for the loss of his prize. This again refers to Agamemnon's  v. 118.  Booty taken on their marauding expeditions was the common property of the army after the several prizes of honor (, v. 185) had been selected for the chiefs, cf. vs. 368 f.,  41 f.;  534 of Achilles's son returning from Troy,  (),  232. These prizes were sometimes selected by the leaders themselves, as  f.,  f., 704; but are often spoken of as the gift of the people, vs. 276, 369, 392,  160, 550 f. Doubtless they were distributed by the general, with the approval of the army. Thus, , Agamemnon is said by Achilles to have given Briseis to him.

: the hero of the Odyssey, the wise  Ithacan prince () by whose device of the wooden horse Ilios was captured (). He is sent in charge of the expedition to restore Chryseis to her father, v. 311. He restrains the Achaeans from following a mad impulse to set out for home,  ff.; he chastises Thersites,  ff. His personal appearance as an orator is described,  ff. He is sent as an envoy to Achilles in the Ninth Book. He enters the Trojan camp as a spy, with Diomed, in the Tenth Book. He is the special favorite of Athene, see on .  Agamemnon expresses his sovereignty in an arbitrary way, declaring his absolute authority over the three mightiest princes of the army.

p.title: Odyssey
p.#text: : the oldest and wisest of the Achaeans before Troy. He often gives good advice, as  ff., 336 ff.,  ff.,  ff.,  ff. He was the most skilled of the Greeks in marshalling the army for battle, cf.  297 ff. He is fond of relating his exploits, as his defeat of Ereuthalion  ff.,  ff. He tells a long story of his first battle against the Eleans,  ff. The Third Book of the  is devoted to the visit of Telemachus, Odysseus's son, to Nestor, at his home in Pylos. f. : Lapithae, a Thessalian mountain-folk famed for its conflict with the centaurs. This strife began at the wedding feast of Peirithous (a friend of Theseus) because of the insolence of the intoxicated centaurs; cf.  ff.,  ff. The battle furnished subjects for the sculptures in the west pediment of the temple of Zeus at Olympia, for the metopes on the south side of the Parthenon at Athens, for the frieze of the temple of Apollo at Phigalia, and for the frieze of the  tomb of Mausolus (the Mausoleum) at Halicarnassus, as well as for vases and other works of art.

p.title: Iliad.
p.#text: : Patroclus was so well known to the hearers of Homer, from old stories and songs, that he needed no more exact designation here; cf. the use of  v. 7. See  21 b. When a boy in Opus he killed a comrade in a fit of anger and was taken by his father to Phthia where Peleus received him kindly ( ff.), and brought him up with Achilles. He attended Achilles on this Trojan ex pedition as his warmest and most faithful friend and squire ( 80 ff.,  ff.). The narrative of his exploits fills a large part of the Sixteenth Book of the  He was slain by Hector ( ff.). To avenge his death, Achilles ends his quarrel with Agamemnon. Most of the Twenty-third Book is occupied with an account of the funeral games in his honor.

title: Iliad
Iliad.
p.#text: : as his mother had directed, vs. 421 f.; cf. vs. 428 f.  Achilles withdraws from the action for the present. In the Ninth Book, an embassy is sent to him, begging him to give up his wrath and take part in the war ( ff.). In the Eleventh Book, he is roused from his apathy on seeing the rout of the Achaeans ( ff.). In the Sixteenth Book, when Hector reaches the Greek ships and throws fire into one of them, Achilles sends Patroclus and the Myrmidons into the conflict ( ff.). He receives the news of the death of Patroclus in the Eighteenth Book ( ff.), and is reconciled to Agamemnon in the Nineteenth Book and arms himself for battle ( ff., 364 ff.). He takes part in the fourth (and last) great battle of the , on the 27th day of the action of the

p.#text: Zeus prepares to fulfil his promise to Thetis ( f., 523) by sending a dream to Agamemnon. The intended battle, which is to be disastrous to the Achaeans, is delayed by a test of the disposition of the army; the Greek and Trojan forces do not advance to meet each other until the close of the book (vs. 780, 809 f.). title: Germ.

p.#text: : a frequent epith. of the Achaeans. Among them to cut the hair was a sign of mourning, cf. , 135 f., 141,  46. Achilles's hair which he cuts off at the funeral pile of Patroclus is called  142, , and the hair of the other heroes floated in the breeze, . Paris is proud of his hair, . Apollo is  39 (Milton's unshorn Apollo). On archaic works of art the men are always represented with long hair. See on v. 872. The Euboean Abantes are  v. 542; their back hair only was long, their front hair was banged (see on v. 542; of course, no Chinese cue is to be thought of in their case). The Thracians are  533, with their hair bound in a knot on top of the head; cf. apud Suevos, usque ad canitiem, horrentem capillum retro sequuntur, ac saepe in ipso solo vertice religant Tac.  38. Thucydides (i. 6) says it was not long since the gentlemen of the old school had given up wearing their hair in a knot fastened by a golden cicada. The Spartans retained to a late period the custom of wearing long hair. Before the battle of Thermopylae, the Persian scouts saw the Spartans combing their hair (Hdt. vii. 208), preparing for glorious victory or honorable death. Among the Hebrews, the long  hair of Absalom is familiar to us. In the later classical period, fashions changed. Only dandies wore long hair at Athens in the time of Aristophanes; and in the post-classical period St. Paul could write to the Corinthians:  1  xi. 14.

p.#text: : for the accent, see  2 w, 41  . This upper garment was put on when no armor was worn. The skin of some wild beast was sometimes worn in its stead, cf.  23, 177 (lion's skin), 29 (leopard's skin). The Homeric hero generally carried a lance, even on a peaceful journey, cf. , 256; but Agamemnon here takes his sword since he could not carry conveniently both lance and . The sword was little used in combat, but often worn, cf.  3.

.: Hermes, the messenger of the gods, bore the  from Zeus to Pelops, as a symbol of empire. The kingdom descended with the sceptre. Pelops, son of Tantalus, went from Lydia to Elis, won the hand of the princess Hippodamia in a chariot race (hence , equiv. to ), established his rule, and gave its name to Peloponnesus (a name not found in Homer).

p.title: An.
p.#text: For this , cf. the speeches of Clearchus and his , Xen.  i. 3. 9 f. Agamemnon does not desire his arguments to be convincing; he reminds his men covertly of the promise of Zeus that they should capture Troy, and that nine years of the ten were already past; he calls that man  who returns to Argos with his end unattained, esp. since they had already remained so long before Ilios; he exaggerates the disparity of numbers of Achaeans and Trojans.

:  Agamemnon in testing the temper of his army complains of his infatuation only as a pretence; in v. 114 he utters unconsciously the unpleasant truth, while in the Ninth Book he uses the same words in bitter earnest.

p.title: The insolent Thersites and his chastisement.

p.#text: : for the hiatus, cf. vs. 216, 315; see  9 b.

: from , the Aeol. form of  , see  4 f. The name () appears in a Thessalian inscription of 214 B.C. It is noteworthy that the poet does not say from what country of Greece Thersites came, and thus offends no one by the episode. Thersites makes his cause odious by his advocacy of it. The vulgar demagogue was intended by the poet to awaken antipathy, and thus is represented to be just as disagreeable and deformed in body as in character. The Greeks always associated a beautiful soul with a beautiful person.

title: the longings and sighs of Helen, i.e.
Aen.
p.#text: : chiastic with , with which it is coincident. The Trojans shall be repaid, like for like..:  those which she felt and uttered. The poet attributes to Nestor a knowledge of Helen's repentance (see on ) and earnest longing to return to Greece (see  f., and Helen's words  260 ff.). Paris is everywhere in Homer held chiefly responsible for Helen's fault, although she followed him willingly; no unattractive picture of her is presented. Vergil ( vi. 511 ff.) represents Helen in a much more unpleasant light.
: cf. v. 171; in a threatening tone. Only let him prepare to depart! Instead of returning as he wishes, before the rest, he will find death here, before the rest. For the imv., cf.  18. .: as v. 170.

p: The Catalogue seems to be prepared for an account of the mustering of the Greeks at Aulis and the embarcation thence (cf. v. 509 f.), and to have been inserted here with divers alterations. We expect here an account of the forces, not of the ships.

p.#text: The nations, their leaders, and the number of their ships are enumerated in a definite geographical order, in three principal divisions: I. () The main land of Greece south of Thermopylae; () middle and southern Greece with the islands immediately adjoining. 16 contingents. (Vs. 494644.) II. Insular Greece, from Crete to Calydnae. 4 contingents. (Vs. 645-680.) III. Thessalian Greece, from Mts. Oeta and Othrys on the south, to Olympus on the north. 9 contingents. (Vs. 681-759.)The Greeks valued this list highly, because of its geographical and statistical information. It was their Domesday Book. They looked upon it as a part of history, a versified geography and gazetteer. They appealed to it to settle disputed questions, and the charge of interpolating verses in it was like a charge of falsifying public records. The geographer Strabo bases upon it his account of Greece.

title: Iliad
Iliad.
p.#text: The poet evidently desires to represent this expedition as a great national undertaking. He enumerates even those nations which from their inland position were not likely to have had anything to do with such a war, e.g. the Arcadians (vs. 603-614), who are not mentioned in the rest of the  as taking part in the battles on the plain of Troy. The poet does not seem to exalt one nation at the expense of another, either here or in the other parts of the  A bard wandering from country to country would acquire a wealth of geographical information, but would form no strong local attachments.

The Achaean ships number in all 1186. The number of men on each ship is stated for only two contingents: each Boeotian ship carried 120 men (v. 510); each of the ships of Philoctetes brought 50 men (v. 719). The ships of Achilles also brought each 50 men (). From the average of the two numbers given for the Boeotians and the ships of Philoctetes, the ancients reckoned the whole number of Achaeans before Troy as about 100,000 (cf. Thuc. i. 10. 33 f.). Others reckoned the ships roundly as 1200, assigned 100 men to  each ship, and thus estimated the whole number of Achaeans as 120,000.  and the  are restricted to a part of Thessaly, vs. 683 f. The Dorians and Ionians are not mentioned. No Greek colonies are known, whether in Asia Minor, in Sicily and the West, or elsewhere. The names Peloponnesus, Attica, Eleusis, Megara, Delphi, Olympia and Pisa, do not appear. Thus this catalogue seems to have been composed before the Dorian migration into Peloponnesus, and the sending forth of colonies to Asia Minor etc.

p.title: Greece south of Thermopylae, with the adjoining islands.
Boeotia, Phocis, Locris, Euboea, Athens, Salamis.
p.#text: 494-558.  The enumeration proceeds from Boeotia in a northerly direction, then to the east, then southward, and so to the west, around Boeotia. Seven contingents; 262 ships.
The poet begins with Boeotia, prob. because the fleet collected at Aulis (v. 303). Because of this beginning, the ancients gave the name  or  to the catalogue of the ships.

p.title: Boeotia.
p.#text: 494-510.  This document presents a distribution of the Greeks such as existed after the Trojan war. Acc. to Thuc. i. 12, the Boeotians lived in Thessaly until sixty years after the fall of Troy. See on v. 507. More towns are mentioned in Boeotia than elsewhere. This last fact may indicate not a Boeotian poet, but the extent of the culture and history of the country. Thebes is not mentioned; see on v. 505.
: correl. with  511. The five leaders are all mentioned elsewhere: the two first,  601 ff.; the other three were killed: Arcesilaus by Hector (), Prothonor by Pulydamas (), Clonius by Agenor ().

: the rich capital of the famous empire of the Minyae; called  in distinction from the Arcadian city (v. 605). Its wealth is mentioned in the same connection as that of Aegyptian Thebes (). Agamemnon in Hades ( ff.) asks Odysseus whether he had heard of his son Orestes at Orchomenus or Pylus. The so-called Treasury of Minyas at Orchomenus resembles the subterranean structures of Mycenae (see on v. 569). Orchomenus was famous for its worship of the Graces, who were said to have been first worshipped there. Both Orchomenus and Aspledon (a small town) lay near Lake Copas, on the left bank of the Boeotian Cephisus (see on v. 522), on the fertile plain of Boeotia. The realm of the Minyae did not become Boeotian until later.

p.#text: : Att. , cf. : preHellenic Thracians who from the Phocian town Abae migrated to Euboea, and gave to the island its earlier name. cf. ,    Hes. Frag. 3.

: the chief town of Euboea, on the strait of Euripus at its very narrowest part; separated from Boeotia by a channel so narrow that plans are making to blast away the rocks, in order to open the way for steamers of ordinary size. In the early times of Greek history, Chalcis exhausted its own strength by sending out colonies,founding the first Greek settlement in the West (Cumae in Campania), and the first in Sicily (Naxos, about 735 B.C.), and sending so many colonies to the southern shore of Thrace as to give its name to the great promontory of Chalcidice.

Columns and other architectural fragments of the pre-Persian Parthenon are found built into the wall of the Acropolis.

: Salamis forms a sort of stepping-stone in the enumeration, as the poet passes from Middle Greece to Peloponnesus. Telamon had removed to Salamis from Aegina (the home of his father Aeacus), because of the murder of his brother.

: for the use of the partic., cf.  v. 525.Ajax here is brought into such close connection with Athens that he appears as a national hero of Attica. This was in accord with the later Athenian tradition. One of the ten tribes () of Attica was named , after him.

: as of Gortyna v. 646; , lit.  (cf.  165), since Tiryns was famous for its walls, the best known and oldest example of the so-called Cyclopean architecture. These walls are thought to have been 50 or 60 feet in hight, and in places are 20 or 25 feet thick. In the time of Antoninus Pius, they were declared to be as great a wonder as the Aegyptian pyramids. Excavations were conducted there by Dr. Schliemann in 1884-85, laying bare the plan of an extensive and elaborate structure.
: famous for the worship of Poseidon, and as the early home of Theseus.
: for the form, see on  v. 503.

: famed for its temple of Asclepius. The theatre (built under the direction of the famous sculptor Polycleitus, with seats and orchestra still well preserved), and other ruins there, were excavated during 1881 and the following years.
: this island in very early times was conquered by Epidaurus. In the eighth century B.C., it was ruled by Pheidon of Argos.
: does not differ materially from  v. 281.
: see on v. 408.

: son of Tydeus. Tydeus was son of Oeneus of Calydon, and brother of Meleager (v. 642); having slain some relative, he fled to Argos where he married a daughter () of King Adrastus (see on v. 572). He fell in the first Argive expedition against Thebes. Diomed took part in the second expedition (that of the ) against Thebes. He was one of the bravest and mightiest of the Achaeans before Troy. The Fifth Book is devoted to his exploits, in the course of which he wounds Aphrodite and (aided by Athena) even Ares. He has a famous meeting with Glaucus ( ff.). He visits the Trojan camp in company with Odysseus, and slays the Thracian Rhesus ( ff.). He reached Argos in safety at the close of the war (, 130 ff.).
: often mentioned in Homer as   and charioteer of Diomed. The name is a short form of , and thus corresponds to .

: The residence <*>f Agamemnon whose realm lay in Nor<*> ern Peloponnesus (the latter Achaea), extending to Elis. Above the gate of the citadel remains the sculptured representation of two lions, prob. the earliest extant specimen of Greek sculpture on Greek soil. Near the citadel are great subterranean structures, of which the finest and largest is the so-called treasure house of Atreus. Mycene (the sing. form also is used, see  19 j) is called by Homer   52, and , 180. The latter epith. was shown to be justified by the discoveries in the excavations by Dr. Schliemann in 1876-77.

In this harbor (then called Navarino), Oct. 20, 1827, the Turkish fleet was nearly annihilated, and the Greek war for independence virtually decided.  The realm of Nestor was founded by his father Neleus (son of Poseidon), who had been driven from Iolcos in Thessaly by his brother Pelias (cf. v. 715).

p.title: The Arcadians.
p.#text: 603-614.  The Arcadians are not mentioned as taking part in any of the conflicts before Troy. They may be thought of as closely connected with (or included among) the forces of Agamemnon.

:  For the use of the adj., see on  v. 20. Aepytus, son of Elatus, was an old Arcadian hero whose descendants reigned long in Arcadia. His mound, which in the time of the early Roman emperors still rested on its circle of stones, reminds scholars of the German graves of the Huns.

: sc. . For the omission of the copula in a rel. clause<*> cf.  : elsewhere only an epith. of the Dardanians in the formula  173. These are combatants with sword, spear, and battle-axe, in contrast with bowmen, slingers, or javelin-throwers. The Arcadians are called  134.

p.#text: <*>.: the Catalogue contains several such references to events which do not fall within the time of the action of the   vs. 690 ff., 699 ff.  A prophet declared that Troy could be taken only with the help of the arrows of Heracles that Philoctetes had in his possession. Acc. to Sophocles in his tragedy , the hero was brought from Lemnos to Troy by Odysseus and Neoptolemus (son of Achilles). No other allusion to this story is found in the Homeric poems. p.#text: : with hypothetical subjv., cf. : a mighty giant, symbol of volcanic power. He opposed Zeus, but was overcome by the thunderbolt, and was buried under a mountain. p.title: Iliad
p.#text: : Iris turns to address Hector as the commander-in-chief, on whom above all others depends the weal of the state; cf.  ()  (sc. Hecuba)  432 ff. Hector was the mightiest of the fifty sons of Priam,  ff. In Z is the account of an affectionate meeting of Hector and his wife Andromache; in H, Hector fights in single combat with Telamonian Ajax; he breaks his way  through the gates of the Greek camp, M 445 ff.; he is grievously wounded by Ajax,  ff., but Apollo restores his strength, and he returns to the conflict,  ff., and advances to the very ships of the Achaeans,  ff.; he slays Patroclus, the friend of Achilles,  ff.; he is himself slain by Achilles, . The Twentyfourth Book tells the story of Priam's visit to the Achaean camp to ransom Hector's body. The last verse of the  is : for the order of words, see on A 282.

p.title: The Trojans and their Allies.
p.#text: 816-877.  The force opposed to the Achaeans is composed of sixteen contingents: I. five contingents from Trojan peoples (vs. 816-839), and II. eleven contingents of allies (, vs. 840-877). Of the allies, three divisions come from Europe, and eight from Asia. I. Trojans from () Ilios, () Dardania, () Zelea, () Adrastea, () Percote etc.; II. Allies (from Europe), () Thracians, () Ciconians, () Paeonians; (from Asia), () Pelasgians, () Paphlagonians, () Halizonians, () Mysians, () Phrygians, () Maeonians, () Carians, () Lydians.

The catalogue of the Trojans is far less exact and detailed than that of the Achaeans; it contains no definite statements of number. The total number of Trojans and allies was 50,000, acc. to  f.: A thousand fires were kindled on the plain, and by each sat fifty men. Of these about 12,000 were Trojans, if vs. 123130 are to be interpreted literally. The Catalogue does not name the  and  ( 86). In  519-522, other troops are mentioned as reinforcements.

The geographer Stephanus of Byzantium enumerates ten towns of this name, besides the citadel Larissa of Argos. Strabo (xiii. 620) enumerates three in Asia Minor: one in sight of Ilios, another near Ephesus, and a third near Cyme; he holds the last to be the one in the poet's mind here, because of  where  Ilippothous falls .

: second only to Hector; the bravest leader of the allies, regarded by the Trojans as  549  He was son of Zeus and Laodamia, Bellerophon's daughter,  f. He led in the attack on the Achaean camp, M 101, 292 ff., 397 ff. He was slain by Patroclus,  ff. At the command of Zeus, Apollo bathed his corpse, anointed it with ambrosia and gave it to the twin brothers, Sleep and Death, to convey to Lycia,  ff.

: Glaucus tells of his race, Z 145 ff. He was first cousin of Sarpedon and grandson of Bellerophon, descended from Sisyphus of Corinth. He is associated with Sarpedon in the battles. He has a famous meeting with Diomed,  ff. He was wounded by Teucer,  ff. The honors received by the two Lycian heroes at home, are enumerated by Sarpedon, .  The name Lycia is given by the poet also to the district from which Pandarus (v. 827) comes, cf. . From those Trojan Lycians, the Southern Lycians of Sarpedon are to be distinguished.
: mentioned also  313; to be distinguished from the Trojan river  74

p: Instead of the general battle which was to be expeeted from the preparations of the Second Book, a duel is fought between Menelaus and Paris. This duel is intended by the combatants to put an end to the entire war.
In the Third Book, the poet gives to his hearers a view of the state of affairs in Troy, as the preceding Books had taught of the relations existing between the Achaeans, both leaders and men.

: Pittheus, king of Troezene, was son of Pelops. His daughter Aethra bore Theseus to Aegeus, king of Athens. She, living in Athens, had under her care Helen whom Theseus had carried off from Sparta, until Castor and Polydeuces freed their sister Helen and captured Aethra at or near Athens. So Aethra was made  Helen's slave, first in Sparta and afterwards in Ilios. But this seems to be a post-Homeric story.

p.title: Iliad
p.#text: The beginning of the next Book transports the hearers to Olympus, where Hera contrives a breach of the treaty. She cannot consent to any peace that would return Helen and the treasures to Menelaus but would leave unsacked the city that she hated. The Trojans discuss among themselves the return of Helen,  ff.  The Lycian archer Pandarus () shot an arrow and wounded Menelaus at the suggestion of Athena ( ff.) Agamemnon thereupon roused the Greek forces, and the opposing armies meet in battle near the close of the Fourth Book ( ff.). Most of the Fifth Book is devoted to the exploits of Diomed (). In the Sixth Book, Hector visits the city, tells the matrons to pray to Athena, and bids farewell to Andromache. In the Seventh Book, Hector and Ajax meet in single combat but night separates them, and the 22d day of the action of the  ends.
